title: When will the International Monetary Fund (IMF) approve release of the next tranche of its loan to Ukraine?
preds:
IMF board approves $1 billion loan disbursement to Ukraine
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-imf-idUSKCN11K2VH?il=0

I am not expecting any negative surprises tomorrow.  If the IMF was going to delay or deny the requested disbursement, I think we'd be reading more from the IMF about "unresolved problems" and more from Ukraine about how "rigid and demanding" the IMF is.

http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-11/ukraine-chases-cuts-in-unrealistic-budget-to-meet-imf-pact "“To restore the relationship with the IMF, to renew external financing -- that was a priority for me and I can put a tick mark there,” Finance Minister Oleksandr Danylyuk said.

Ukraine approves 2016 budget, clearing way for delayed IMF loan
http://www.dw.com/en/ukraine-approves-2016-budget-clearing-way-for-delayed-imf-loan/a-18941631

http://www.reuters.com/article/ukraine-cenbank-imf-idUSS8N16N03Y " . . .The IMF announced on Wednesday that it would discuss disbursing a new loan on Sept 14 . . ."
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  My understanding of this question is that it is not about the release date, but about the approval date. I don't know IMF "code talk", but normally a discussion and a decision are 2 different things, so I'm not going to go 100% on the "before Oct 1" option.   As @sevedb has pointed out (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/318548) " . . .some technical issues regarding the timing of future actions by Ukraine's government were still being resolved" could be code for "the Ukraine government needs to do some things before another loan will be made".
After further thought I was to conservative with 45% before Oct 1. Ukraine is probably on the agenda because the IMF intends to release some funds.

I was severely punished for my too optimistic assumption on the previous question for July meeting. Still... Ukrainians do show some progress in cleaning their mess though not enough in tackling corruption. Most probably, without political component IMF would defer further (as they did actually). But there is a political component that is demonstrated by IMF's change of heart.
Hence, the probability is great that IMF will approve the next tranche. Most probably it will be smaller than expected, symbolical to show the IMF support and displeasure at the same time, but which will also allow for the US approve its loan to Ukraine.

"The IMF announced on Wednesday that it would discuss disbursing a new loan on Sept 14, part of a $17.5 billion bailout for Ukraine's war-battered economy."
"Ukraine cbank: new IMF tranche to cut currency volatility"
http://www.reuters.com/article/ukraine-cenbank-imf-idUSS8N16N03Y

Ukraine's central bank said on Thursday that a new aid tranche from the International Monetary Fund would reduce volatility in the currency market and underpin reforms that are key to putting Ukraine on a path of sustainable economic growth. The IMF announced on Wednesday that it would discuss disbursing a new loan on Sept 14, part of a $17.5 billion bailout for Ukraine's war-battered economy. "...a positive decision of the Fund will eliminate the psychological pressure on the foreign exchange market and support the trend towards a decrease in the hryvnia exchange rate volatility, the first signs of which were observed in the last few days," the bank said on its website. (Reporting by Natalia Zinets; Writing by Matthias Williams; Editing by Toby Chopra)
++++++++
The IMF has the meeting on its agenda for September 14th; by now they had plenty time to discuss the findings of the mission and the report prepared by the staff. The agreement may be very close.
Odds go up because they are on the calendar for Sept 14th but that does not guarantee release of funds.

IMF meeting on the 14th to approve the next tranche.
https://www.imf.org/external/NP/SEC/bc/eng/index.aspx

My actual answer is zero for all three questions but the web site won't allow me to put zero as the answer for some reason. I think when a new President is sworn in the odds change not before. so just to get the answer to register I will put 100% for Jan 1 2017

Tough call for the IMF:  Ukraine's progress on reforms could be outrun by a reasonably brisk glacier, but nobody wants to leave them to the tender mercies of Vlad the Shirtless either.  They may slip Poroshenko a few bucks, more as a symbol than anything else.  But they may not.

This information may mean very little in terms of disbursement
http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/367772.html WASHINGTON, Sept 1 (Reuters) - The International Monetary Fund board is expected to consider releasing the next tranche of Ukraine's bailout at a meeting in the second half of September, IMF spokesman Gerry Rice said on Thursday.  "Discussions have continued in recent days, they are very close to being finalized," Rice said of the Ukraine review, noting that some technical issues regarding the timing of future actions by Ukraine's government were still being resolved. (Reporting by David Lawder; Editing by Andrea Ricci)
Read more: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-3769109/IMF-says-expects-board-consider-Ukraine-fund-release-soon.html#ixzz4JUFLTXHm  ++++++
The above however means that not all is well: "Rice said of the Ukraine review, noting that some technical issues regarding the timing of future actions by Ukraine's government were still being resolved" The next press briefing will be on Sept. 15; some veiled information may come then.

There is not much on the subject on Google past the July news that the IMF might review it after the summer holidays. If there was something positive then Ukraine media would have published it. This lack of news suggests that things are not moving that way. There was also a reference that President of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko expressed his confidence that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will, in the near future, announce its decision regarding the disbursement of the third loan tranche [1]. If this was going to take place in the next few months then he would have said so.  Interestingly, the consensus started with a low probability for "before the October 2016" option, it then jumped up and it is now trending down, while the "after the January 2017" option is trending up. It could be that the difference between this forecast and the consensus is partially attributable to out of date forecasts in the consensus.  [1] http://www.unian.info/economics/1503149-imf-to-disburse-next-loan-tranche-to-ukraine-soon-poroshenko.html

Not in September
EU officials report only 2 of 15 reforms are complete.
Privatization still too low.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-eurozone-greece-esm-idUSKCN11A11A?il=0

For as much as the West is eager to help Ukraine from falling into Russia’s orbit again, IMF cannot hand Ukraine’s corrupt government billions of dollars and expect any positive outcome. Reforms need to be made, and efforts must be put long before anything will start to move regarding funds to Ukraine. These changes require a long time, and Poroshenko is moving a bit slow if, at all.

This money has been on hold for quite a while and the new e-declaration system may be enough to make it happen before the close of the year but since they are not on the IMF September calendar probably not by Oct 1.

IMF "expects its board to consider releasing additional funds in the second half of September, according to Reuters." http://www.unian.info/economics/1499104-reuters-imf-says-nearing-board-vote-to-release-ukraine-bailout-funds.html

unrelated but not unrelated 
http://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-defense/2075954-ukraine-receives-military-aid-from-western-allies-lysenko.html
The Armed Forces of Ukraine have received more than 1,000 night vision devices from the United States. Spokesman for the Presidential Administration on the ATO, Colonel Andriy Lysenko said this at a briefing in Kyiv, an Ukrinform correspondent reported. "The Armed Forces of Ukraine have recently received more than 1,000 night vision devices from the United States. The same number of devices will come in the near future," he said. According to him, since the beginning of 2016 Ukraine has received the international technical assistance in the amount of USD 62 million and the humanitarian aid worth USD 7 million.
I'm leaning heavily for right after 1 Jan just because of the Book keeping advantages...

"Given that corruption concerns were the main reason for the IMF and EU to postpone their funding in early 2016, a perfectly functional e-declaration system will become the main precondition to resume any Western financing," Concorde's Paraschiy added on August 22. "To make matters worse, after the attempts of authorities to undermine the launch of e-declaration, Western observers might be inclined to take some additional time to be reassured that there is no reverse or derailment of this reform." According to Poroshenko, the system will be launched on September 1. However, even if everything goes smoothly with the introduction of the e-declaration system, observers say October will be the earliest time any funding might arrive.
http://www.intellinews.com/imf-delays-review-of-ukraine-funding-amid-anti-corruption-system-doubts-104494/
They need the money to pay for Russian gas
At least a reduced amount.  They made their signal already.

Ukraine is currently not on the IMF calendar for September.  Forecasting the e-declaration process (described below), due to come on line Sept 1., might demonstrate some progress to the IMF.  Ukraine had reportedly been close in July 2016: http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/international-monetary-fund-imf-could-resume-aid-to-ukraine-in-july-spokesman-2914379/ From: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-imf-idUSKCN11527Z
"Months of political infighting have held up IMF-backed legislative changes aimed at limiting the power of vested interests and modernizing the economy." Ukranian Finance Minister: "Danylyuk said the launch of an e-declaration system to improve transparency of the income and assets of public officials, linked to the IMF deal, would go smoothly after some problems this month.  "On Sept. 1 this system will be launched fully, which is in line with all our international obligations. And, what is more important, which is in line with our ambitions," he said. "Danylyuk said the Ukraine government was committed to implementing a wide-ranging reform agenda. 
     First, an energy reform must be completed, including the full market liberalisation of the gas sector from April 
     followed by a market reform of the electricity market."
    Other priorities include overhauls in Ukraine's health and education systems, as well as a budget reform. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-ukraine-crisis-imf-idUSKCN11527Z
